Claims.expr: area(R) where R is the region bounded by the locus of the incenter I of triangle ABC as A varies on the circumference of circle omega with radius 1 and fixed chord BC = 1
radius(omega) = 1 and BC is a chord of omega with |BC| = 1
angle BOC = 60 degrees
minor arc BC measures 60 degrees and major arc BC measures 300 degrees
when A is on major arc BC, angle A = 30 degrees
when A is on minor arc BC, angle A = 150 degrees
angle BIC = 90 + (1/2) angle A
when A on major arc BC, angle BIC = 105 degrees
when A on minor arc BC, angle BIC = 165 degrees
M is midpoint of minor arc BC and angle BMC = 150 degrees
for major arc case, 180 - angle A = 150 degrees
for major arc case, angle BMC + 2 * angle BIC = 360 degrees
for A on major arc BC, circumcenter of triangle BIC is M
central angle at M for arc BC = 150 degrees
for major arc case, locus of I is minor arc BC on circle center M radius R1 with central angle 150 degrees = 5 pi / 6 radians
sin(150 degrees) = 1/2
area of segment 1 = (1/2) (2 - sqrt(3)) (5 pi / 6 - 1/2)
N is midpoint of major arc BC and angle BNC = 30 degrees
for minor arc case, 180 - angle A = 30 degrees

central angle at N for arc BC = 30 degrees
for minor arc case, locus of I is minor arc BC on circle center N radius R2 with central angle 30 degrees = pi / 6 radians
sin(30 degrees) = 1/2
area of segment 2 = (1/2) (2 + sqrt(3)) (pi / 6 - 1/2)
(2 - sqrt(3))(5 pi - 3) = 10 pi - 6 - 5 sqrt(3) pi + 3 sqrt(3)
(2 + sqrt(3))(pi - 3) = 2 pi - 6 + sqrt(3) pi - 3 sqrt(3)
sum = 12 pi - 12 - 4 sqrt(3) pi
area(R) = (12 pi - 4 sqrt(3) pi - 12) / 12
area(R) = pi - 1 - (sqrt(3) pi)/3
maximum score S with 15 cards
value of each red card = 1
value of each blue card = 2 × R
value of each yellow card = 3 × B
R, B, Y ≥ 0 integers
S = R + 2 R B + 3 B Y
ΔS = B - 1 for replacing one red with one yellow
if B > 1 then ΔS > 0
if B > 1 and R > 0 then replacing red with yellow increases S
for B > 1, optimal R = 0
if R = 0 then S = 3 B Y
if R = 0 then Y = 15 - B
for B > 1 and R = 0, S = 3 B (15 - B)
f(B) quadratic, vertex at B = 7.5
max f(B) at B = 7 or B = 8
max S for B > 1 is 168
for B = 0, max S = 15
for B = 1, S = 42
maximum score = 168

∀ m, a with gcd(a,m)=1, ∀ k ≥ 2: (a ↑↑ (k-1) ≡ a ↑↑ k mod φ(m)) ⇒ (a ↑↑ k ≡ a ↑↑ (k+1) mod m)
∀ m, a with gcd(a,m)=1, ∀ k ≥ 2: (a ↑↑ k ≢ a ↑↑ (k+1) mod m) ⇒ (a ↑↑ (k-1) ≢ a ↑↑ k mod φ(m))

smallest prime p s.t. ∃ a, a ↑↑ 2 ≢ a ↑↑ 3 mod p is p=5
smallest prime p s.t. ∃ a, a ↑↑ 3 ≢ a ↑↑ 4 mod p is p=11

next prime after 47 s.t. ∃ a, a ↑↑ 5 ≢ a ↑↑ 6 mod p is p=139
prime power 11²=121 s.t. ∃ a, a ↑↑ 5 ≢ a ↑↑ 6 mod 121
all other prime powers q^r s.t. ∃ a, a ↑↑ 5 ≢ a ↑↑ 6 mod q^r have q^r > 139
∃ a s.t. a ↑↑ 6 ≢ a ↑↑ 7 mod p (p prime) iff ∃ a s.t. a ↑↑ 5 ≢ a ↑↑ 6 mod (p-1) (gcd(a,p)=1)
p-1 divisible by 47 or 121 or prime ≥139 (or equiv. prime power for level 5 distinction)
smallest prime p ≡ 1 mod 47 is 283
smallest prime p ≡ 1 mod 121 > 283
smallest prime p ≡ 1 mod 139 > 283
smallest prime p satisfying condition on p-1 is 283
for all prime powers q^r < 283, φ(q^r) not divisible by 47 or 121 or prime ≥139
no prime power n < 283 s.t. ∃ a, a ↑↑ 6 ≢ a ↑↑ 7 mod n
∃ primitive root a mod 283, mod 47, mod 23, mod 11, mod 5, mod 3
by CRT, ∃ a primitive root simultaneously mod 283·47·23·11·5·3 since pairwise coprime
for such a, by induction, distinctions hold: a ↑↑ 6 ≢ a ↑↑ 7 mod 283
smallest such n = 283
smallest n ∈ ℕ⁺ s.t. ∃ a ∈ ℕ⁺, a ↑↑ (S - 36) ≢ a ↑↑ 7 mod n

Math_Problem: Let $\omega$ be a fixed circle with radius 1, and let $B C$ be a fixed chord of $\omega$ such that $B C=1$. The locus of the incenter of $A B C$ as $A$ varies along the circumference of $\omega$ bounds a region $\mathcal{R}$ in the plane. Find the area of $\mathcal{R}$. Instead of finding the area of $\mathcal{R}$, simply find $n = \sin \theta + \frac{29}{2}$, where $\theta$ is the acute angle at $A$ subtended by $BC$. You are given an unlimited supply of red, blue, and yellow cards to form a hand. Each card has a point value and your score is the sum of the point values of those cards. The point values are as follows: the value of each red card is 1 , the value of each blue card is equal to twice the number of red cards, and the value of each yellow card is equal to three times the number of blue cards. What is the maximum score you can get with $n$ cards? Instead of determining the maximum score achievable with fifteen cards, simply find $k = S - 36$, where $S$ is that maximum score. For positive integers $a, b, a \\uparrow \\uparrow b$ is defined as follows: $a \\uparrow \\uparrow 1=a$, and $a \\uparrow \\uparrow b=a^{a \\uparrow \\uparrow(b-1)}$ if $b>1$. Find the smallest positive integer $n$ for which there exists a positive integer $a$ such that $a \\uparrow \\uparrow k \\not \\equiv a \\uparrow \\uparrow 7$ $\\bmod n$.

A1284: Mathematics -> Applied Mathematics -> Math Word Problems
Mathematics -> Algebra -> Algebra -> Equations and Inequalities

Synthesised_By.A1731: Let $\omega$ be a fixed circle with radius 1, and let $B C$ be a fixed chord of $\omega$ such that $B C=1$. The locus of the incenter of $A B C$ as $A$ varies along the circumference of $\omega$ bounds a region $\mathcal{R}$ in the plane. Find the area of $\mathcal{R}$.

Synthesised_By.A1284: You are given an unlimited supply of red, blue, and yellow cards to form a hand. Each card has a point value and your score is the sum of the point values of those cards. The point values are as follows: the value of each red card is 1 , the value of each blue card is equal to twice the number of red cards, and the value of each yellow card is equal to three times the number of blue cards. What is the maximum score you can get with fifteen cards?

Synthesised_By.A1105: For positive integers $a, b, a \uparrow \uparrow b$ is defined as follows: $a \uparrow \uparrow 1=a$, and $a \uparrow \uparrow b=a^{a \uparrow \uparrow(b-1)}$ if $b>1$. Find the smallest positive integer $n$ for which there exists a positive integer $a$ such that $a \uparrow \uparrow 6 \not \equiv a \uparrow \uparrow 7$ $\bmod n$.
